mainText: Google is running their first official DevFest OnAir on December 12th. These community-led developer sessions are hosted by GDG (Google Developer Groups) focused on community, networking and learning about Google technologies. It's free and you can register at g.co/dev/festonair18

Chrome Dev Summit finished last week and here are some highlights. Portals were introduced as a new API proposal which allow you seamless page transitions on the web. A portal element is similar to an iframe, but is always top-level and can be navigated into and out of.

They also announced Squoosh, A 15kb JS-powered web application which handles image compression. If you are interested in web performance you should definitely watch Jake Archibald's talk on how they created the app and what best practices they followed to make sure the app remains 15KB only.

Chrome will soon natively support a lazyload attribute on resources such as images! This attribute will tell the browser to only load the resource when it is needed, for example when it is scrolled into view.

Historically, measuring the performance of a website was split among various tools that could (and probably would) give differing results. Going forward, all of Googleâ€™s tooling for measuring performance across all the various products will now be backed by the new PageSpeed API (version 5), which is essentially a Lighthouse API.
